newsitem.title: PERU: Momentum slows in search for Peru crisis solution.
newsitem.headline: Momentum slows in search for Peru crisis solution.

text.p: Pre-Easter optimism had all but vanished on Monday as Marxist rebels slammed the government for its slow pace in reaching a negotiated solution for Peru's 104-day hostage crisis.
"The slowness is due to the government's intransigency," charged "Comrade Alejandro," a Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA) military leader in Peru's eastern jungle.
"The prisoners' issue is still not resolved," he added in a communication with Reuters. "We will stay (in the residence) as long as is necessary to achieve the freedom of our prisoners."

The MRTA's demand for the release of jailed comrades has been the main sticking point since 20-odd rebels led by Nestor Cerpa blasted their way into the Japanese ambassador's residence during a cocktail party on Dec. 17.

Diplomatic and media circles were convinced last week the government and MRTA were close to an agreement involving asylum in Cuba for the hostage-takers, a possible ransom deal and the release of some lower-level prisoners.

But that optimism was dashed over the weekend as the MRTA made a string of tough public statements via the Internet, a banner draped outside the residence and a walkie-talkie conversation between Cerpa and journalists.
Fujimori said at the weekend he was still hopeful of a solution but was not prepared to shift his position on the prisoners' issue.

"There was a lot of speculation during Holy Week that there would be a peaceful solution, but we were conscious that we were not in the final stage, that the conditions were not right," Fujimori said in a television interview.
"Naturally, we are hopeful that it will be the soonest possible, but we do not foresee a date."

Although tension has been focused on possibilities for a peaceful solution, crack troops have been training in case of an assault and, according to intelligence reports, the MRTA has slipped an extra 70 fighters into Lima as a potential backup for those inside the residence.

Fujimori met on Monday at Government Palace with his chief negotiator in the crisis, Domingo Palermo, and members of a three-man guarantors' committee overseeing negotiations to end Latin America's longest hostage siege.
Japanese government observer Terusuke Terada was also present at the meeting, which lasted nearly two hours.
They made no comment to reporters afterward.

The guarantors have been holding separate "parallel" meetings with the MRTA and the government during a period of "reflection" since the last and 10th round of face-to-face talks on March 12. Last week's speculation focused on a supposed blueprint proposal by the guarantors to end the crisis.

The Vatican's representative on the guarantors' commission, Archbishop Juan Luis Cipriani, denied late on Sunday that talks between the two sides had "broken down" and called for patience and tolerance on all sides.
"We are trying to move as fast as possible," he said.
The mainly middle-aged male hostages spent a quiet Easter weekend under the guns of their MRTA captors with whom they are said to have now formed close personal ties.

The Red Cross took in Easter eggs and fresh fruit along with their usual provisions on Sunday. A special Mass was held for the captives, who have also spent Christmas and the New Year inside the diplomatic compound.
While concern centred on the health of the hostages, Alejandro insisted the jungle-trained rebels inside were still in peak condition. "They are doing well, both physically and morally," he said.
Among the captives are the ambassadors of Japan and Bolivia; Fujimori's brother, Pedro; two Peruvian government ministers; military officers and Japanese businessmen and diplomats.
